rationale: No intensifier or comparative adjective directly modifies a risk-adjective.
No high-potency verb, metaphor, superlative, or critical alert phrase.
The verbs 'has been', 'have been', 'is', and 'was tested' are plain verbs/outcomes, excluded by rule 4.
The segment does not contain a loaded rhetorical question.
This explains the nature of the cases; 'isn't classic influenza at all' is a positive fact but not explicit calming language.
The segment uses 'just' but it modifies the reason for testing, not the scale of cases.
'Neither of these two cases... has been an actual influenza infection' and 'this isnâ€™t classic influenza at all' are bare negations of the infection type without explicit calming.
